content: hey guys welcome back to black magic
crafts this week I'm not really in the mood to build or sculpt anything
original I kind of just want to put something together and paint it I just
want to work on a miniature but I'm not gonna work on a little miniature I'm
gonna put together and paint this shipwreck revenue this is a big pork in
Reaper bones mini that I got in that encounter crate from realm Smith and its
really inspired me I I don't want this just to live in the box of shameful
unpainted miniatures shame shame shame I want to bring this thing to life it
seems like it has a ton of cool details on it and it's gonna be one of those
minis that I can really put a lot of work and effort into the little
embellishments and the base which is my favorite part so that's what we're gonna
do today so I'm gonna open this thing up I'm gonna wash it with soap and water
and I'm gonna start working on it listen I know what some of you are
thinking sitting there going I wish you would just build something not a symbol
of pre-made mini well first of all sometimes you want to assemble and paint
a mini it's a big part of the hobby and it's the part of the hobby I wanted to
enjoy this week more importantly though this is not gonna be a simple mini
painting exercise I'm gonna try a ton of new cool techniques and products on this
both painting and in effects and embellishments there's gonna be a lot of
stuff I do here that can be used in original builds the nice thing about
using someone else's sculpt is that I can go at the painting process fresh and
inspired when I do my own build one thing that sometimes happens is that
by the time I get to the painting portion I'm burnt out and the paint job
gets rushed as a result I don't want to do that here now I'm not an expert mini
painter I do things my own way but I think the final results on this many are
quite good despite trying so many new things on it I spent a fair amount of
time deciding on whether or not I should assemble this piece before painting in
the end I decided I'd rather just build the whole thing and deal with some of
the awkward painting later as a result this way I could fill the gaps before
priming and make some of the lighting effects I wanted to do easier as one
single piece easier than it would be separately I used a cheap superglue to
assemble it and fill the gaps using the baking soda and glue method often on
miniatures I will prefer to use a two-part epoxy putty to fill gaps as
then I can nicely sculpt a let run across the gaps but the downside to
putties is that they need a long time to cure before painting I didn't want to
wait for that and since the gaps on this piece were almost all across sculpted
bits of coral the texture of the baking soda would actually be perfect
I attached the mini to a large pill bottle handle using hot glue for many of
this heavy poster tack is just not strong enough to hold up throughout the
entire mini painting process for primer I went with Vallejo surface primer
airbrushed on this is a fast method that allows for a very thin layer of primer
that bonds well with the bones material for more info on priming bones i will
link to my video on the subject as well as one by blanco where he goes into some
more detailed testing there are a few ways you can do it but the most
important thing is to properly wash and dry the mini before priming
using a bright white I used the zenithal
priming method by spraying white from above at an angle this creates an effect
of a light source on the miniature by highlighting all of the highest points
this effect only really works if you later apply thin coats of color allowing
the variants of dark and light shading in the primer to show through this also
helps to bring out some of the details in the sculpt so that you can easily see
them while painting and have a better idea of what you're actually painting
now when it comes to painting many
skilled and experienced mini painters will spend a lot of time and effort on
single parts of the model one at a time getting them perfect and complete before
moving on to another section I personally have a very difficult time
working in this fashion and prefer to block out all of the colors across the
whole mini and apply washes over several areas at a time because of this I
started by painting out what is the majority of color on this piece and
that's the wood I chose a medium lightness and golden brown this color
looks very much like fresh wood but after all of the washes it will end up
looking aged I also did a dry brushing of a bone white normally I avoid dry
brushing on miniatures as the effect can be pretty heavy-handed looking but the
light gray chalky effect is a great way to make wood look old and weathered I
then painted out all of the metal using a gunmetal metallic the one exception to
this was a lion head carving on his crotch that I painted with a bronze as I
felt that that detail from whatever part of the ship it originated would probably
have been an ornate focal point on the ship and wouldn't have been made of iron
normally as I said I would wait until all the colors are blocked out before
doing washes but I was concerned that the black wash on the wood would ruin
the coral if I did it after so I decided to apply the wash before moving on to
the rest of the paint I painted out the skeleton and the ropes using a bone
white and the coral using a pure bright white I called it a night and let things
dry until the next morning for the skeleton and the ropes I applied a sepia
Brown wash for the coral I wanted it to have a variety of very vibrant colors so
I mixed up some bright color washes I just chose colors that I thought would
be appropriate I made these washes by diluting the paint with pledge floor
polish instead of water as it would help them to flow off all of the high points
better and avoid any splotching while it dried
after the washes were dried I gave the coral a very delicate dry brushing with
bright white just to make sure the high points really stood out now it was time
for the lighting effects from the lantern I wanted the lamp to be casting
a ghostly green hue on the mini so I painted it out with a very vibrant
almost neon green and I used my airbrush and very thinned paint to create the
lighting effects this can be done with a brush but it takes a lot longer and I am
not nearly skilled enough of a painter to achieve that effect manually with a
brush doing it with an airbrush allowed me to spray the miniature from
the direction of the light source and just naturally only hit the high points
that would be in the light path it's a little intimidating to do this to a
piece that you've just spent several hours painting but without taking risks
you learn and achieve nothing now to get this effect I actually did three
different colors through the airbrush first the main green with a very wide
spread then I did a coat of a brighter more yellow-green on a smaller area of
spray finally I did a very refined spray with an almost pure yellow that was very
very thin down after that I increased the effect by using a brush to manually
highlight the highest and sharpest points in the path of the light source
with a pure bright yellow I blended the outer edges of this effect further onto
the mini by applying a very thin wash of the base green color using a paintbrush
at this point I had not yet painted anything on the base because I wanted to
sculpt something first I attached the mini to a wooden disk using hot glue I
then you sculpt a mold to continue the base out that was already on the model
onto the entire circle this was actually the first time I used sculpt a mold and
I have to say I absolutely loved it it was very easy to mix and work with and
it dried super quick after 30 minutes from application you can actually move
on to painting which is awesome when the mixture was very wet it was easy to
spread in shape and once it had slightly hardened after about 15 minutes I was
able to go in and create hard flat surface details and create ROC shapes
sculpt the mold is my new favorite thing I wanted the mini to look like he was
standing right at the shoreline so I painted out the base to look like a
rocky shore and painted the area that I would be doing the water effect with a
very deep deep green but before doing the water effect I
wanted the rest of the mini to be a hundred percent complete and varnished
so I moved on to the next cool detail the seaweed I wanted it to look like
this thing had risen from the depths of the ocean and got seaweed stuck onto its
various parts again I tried something new here I took regular cotton balls and
pulled them apart I dip these in a green wash that I had mixed with a little bit
of PVA glue soaked up some of the excess on a paper towel then drape them over
the mini this worked brilliantly so good and I'm excited to use this effect on
other pieces in the future
the addition of the base sculpt and seaweed was missing the lighting effect
and if you're wondering why I didn't do the base earlier on when I assembled
everything else it's because I thought it would be too big and just too much in
the way when it came to painting at this point the base needed that same lighting
effect so I went back in with the airbrush and carefully applied the same
effect but I did it very lightly and carefully as I didn't want to overdo it
the last step before water effects was the varnish and I chose a gloss varnish
for this piece as I wanted it to look wet that's something you would normally
avoid with most miniatures since I had already been working with the airbrush
so much on this piece I decided hey why not try airbrushing on the gloss varnish
another thing I was trying for the first time it worked out really great and was
a lot less of a pain in the butt in terms of ventilation than a regular
aerosol spray varnish I could finally do the water effects which is what I'd been
excitedly waiting for since assembling the mini for the core of the water
I used my go-to dollar store five minute epoxy it's cheap and most importantly
it's fast I actually wanted to do this using enviro Tex Lite which is a slower
curing resin that's easier to pour but I actually went to Michael's to buy some
and they were sold out so I went back home and used my faithful 5-minute stop
which has the advantage of curing very very quickly using a strip of plastic
from the epoxy packaging I created a dam to contain the resin held it in place
with an elastic band but also did a bead of hot glue on the underside of the base
just just in case I mix the epoxy with a very tiny amount of greenwash and I mean
a tiny tiny amount I wanted it to be slightly tinted to help imply depth but
I still wanted it to be translucent once mixed I poured in the resin and worked
it into all of the low spots with five minute epoxy you have to work quickly
and I need some help flowing but it gets the job done
I considered thinning it with acetone but I wasn't sure if that would end up
melting my in plastic damn and at this point I had
taken more than enough risks on this piece and I didn't want to screw it up
in the final hour I removed the dam after only about two or three minutes as
soon as the epoxy would hold its shape when epoxy cures it gets incredibly hot
so hot that it can actually deform the thin plastic dam and create an odd shape
so I made sure to get it off before it reached its max temperature the excess
resin and hot glue from the dam were easily cleaned up using an exacto knife
to create some more depth and motion in the water
I applied a thin layer of liquid Tex gloss gel to the surface this is a great
way to create waves this can also be done with a gloss gel from golden the
clear water effects from Vallejo a clear acrylic caulking or even gloss Mod Podge
however with the Mod Podge you can't make them as thick of a texture in one
application and you have to do it in layers the stuff to nearly a full 24
hours to cure and go clear while waiting I painted out the ring of the base black
this is a really important step that some people skip but to me it's it's
really the frame that borders your finished piece so I always make sure to
make it nice and clean and refined another thing I did while waiting was to
use some of the same gloss gel to create glass on the lantern the sculpt was
recessed a bit so I was able to fill it with gel medium then scrape it flush
with a toothpick this worked really well and while not an obvious detail I think
it was a nice touch the last thing to do on this piece was to create some foamy
white caps on the crests of the waves for this I used liquitex modeling paste
but again you can use all sorts of things for this like white acrylic
hulking Vallejo snow paste or even just some white paint if you're in a pinch I
was pretty light handed as I didn't want to overdo it but I'll admit that after a
dry die off-camera applied a second much heavier layer as I thought my first
go was too minimal this is by far the most fun I've ever had assembling and
painting and off-the-shelf miniature I tried all sorts of new things and well
they all worked out pretty awesome Lee a lot of these techniques will now find
their way into my other projects and original builds if you want to pick up
any tools or supplies to do your own and support the channel in the process head
over to Blackmagic craft CA where I have my essential equipment store with Amazon
affiliate links to all of the things that I use and recommend I will also put
links to some of the specific items used in this build in the video description
making these videos every week takes an incredible amount of time and effort
even this one where I used an off-the-shelf miniature in the project
was still over 30 hours of work to produce if you love these videos and you
want to help me keep making them you can do so by supporting black magic crafts
on patreon that support gives me the freedom to spend the time making videos
like this and I'd love to have you as the newest member of the black magic
crafts fellowship there you have it guys another project and video complete I
hope you enjoyed this one if you did hit that like button and let me know in the
comments section below while I do hope you learned some specific skills from
this video what I really want you to take away is two messages one if don't
always feel like you have to build what you got to build be it for your YouTube
channel or for your game some days you just might be in the mood to do a
certain thing so do that because you should enjoy the Hobby don't build
things you don't feel like building the other thing I want you to take away from
this is that you should not be afraid to experiment with techniques materials
whatever Lord knows I tried a ton of new things on this guy which was risky but
hey it's just a model you can always repaint it so get out there and try some
crazy things slap some stuff on your models spray them with lighting effects
do whatever anyways guys see again next Cheers
